outputs.executiveOneLiner: Headline value (Gross Margin): £2.0m - all figures expressed on a gross-margin basis.
outputs.executiveSummary: This value case estimates the gross-margin upside from improving LEON’s loyalty personalisation and menu price/markdown discipline, using FY2024 financial scale (£62.5m revenue) and a blended gross margin of ~65.5% derived from disclosed gross profit (£40.92m). [1] We first modelled a midpoint-based base case across levers; because the base case total was below £2.0m GM, we applied the stretch-up rule uniformly across levers (still within evidence-backed ranges). For personalised loyalty, we apply an 18% uplift within McKinsey’s cited 5–25% credible span for personalisation impact. [9] For price optimisation, we apply a conservative 1.7% uplift on total revenue, anchored to a 0.5–2.0% credible proxy range. [10] Strategically, this matters now: LEON’s administration status and challenging trading context increase the urgency of shifting demand to higher-margin, lower-waste repeat behaviour while tightening price architecture to protect margin. [7]

rows.areaOfImpact: A. Personalised Loyalty (incl. offer waste reduction)
rows.opportunityType: Incremental GM from better targeting and reduced discount waste
rows.assumptionsMethodology:
1. UPLIFT POINT APPLIED: We have applied a 18.0% uplift, which represents the upper-mid stretch of the credible range for this lever.
2. RANGE & SOURCE: This sits within the credible category range of 5% to 25%, based on McKinsey’s cited personalisation impact spans. [9]
3. WHY THIS POINT WAS SELECTED: We selected this point because the total value case was below the 2 million pound threshold, which means the model uses the stretch-up rule.
4. SIMPLE MATHS EXPLANATION: In practice, this means applying the 18.0% uplift to loyalty-customer revenue (modelled at £11.25m), and converting this into gross margin using the blended GM% of 65.5%.
5. RESULT: This results in an estimated gross margin uplift of £1.3m for this lever.
6. REASSURANCE: All assumptions sit comfortably within evidence-based bounds and avoid reliance on extreme best-case scenarios.

rows.opportunityType: GM uplift from improved price architecture and markdown management
rows.assumptionsMethodology:
1. UPLIFT POINT APPLIED: We have applied a 1.7% uplift, which represents the upper-mid stretch of the credible range for this lever.
2. RANGE & SOURCE: This sits within the credible category range of 0.5% to 2.0%, based on a conservative proxy range anchored to published retail uplift discussions (used here as a QSR analogue for price/offer discipline). [10]
3. WHY THIS POINT WAS SELECTED: We selected this point because the total value case was below the 2 million pound threshold, which means the model uses the stretch-up rule.
4. SIMPLE MATHS EXPLANATION: In practice, this means applying the 1.7% uplift to total revenue (£62.5m), and converting this into gross margin using the blended GM% of 65.5%.
5. RESULT: This results in an estimated gross margin uplift of £0.7m for this lever.
6. REASSURANCE: All assumptions sit comfortably within evidence-based bounds and avoid reliance on extreme best-case scenarios.
